title: Update regarding FinCorp
story_body:
Industry-Wide Shortages of High-Performance Computing Components Disrupt Financial Sector, FinCorp Among Those Affected

A confluence of factors has culminated in a perfect storm of shortages affecting the global financial sector, with FinCorp (FIN) being one of the many institutions impacted. At the epicenter of this disruption are high-performance computing components, specifically high-bandwidth, low-latency networking equipment and cutting-edge graphics processing units (GPUs).

The shortage of these critical components has been exacerbated by a combination of increased demand from the financial sector, coupled with supply chain constraints and manufacturing capacity limitations. As a result, FinCorp, along with its peers, is facing significant challenges in maintaining optimal performance and capacity in their high-performance computing environments.

The affected components, including 100GbE networking gear and NVIDIA V100 GPUs, are crucial for running complex financial simulations, risk modeling, and high-frequency trading workloads. The lack of availability of these components has forced FinCorp to adopt a 'make-do' approach, utilizing lower-performance alternatives and implementing workload optimization strategies to mitigate the impact on their operations.

Industry benchmarks, such as the Standard Performance Evaluation Corporation (SPEC) CPU2006 and GPU-accelerated STAC-A2, have been adversely affected, with many financial institutions, including FinCorp, reporting significant declines in performance. Specifically, FinCorp's benchmark scores have dropped by an average of 15% across their high-performance computing clusters.

The situation has also led to increased latency and decreased throughput in FinCorp's trading and risk management systems, which could potentially result in increased transaction costs and decreased competitiveness in the market.

As the financial sector continues to rely heavily on high-performance computing, the shortage of these critical components poses a significant risk to the stability and efficiency of global financial markets. FinCorp and its peers are working closely with suppliers to address the shortage, but the situation remains fluid, and a resolution is not expected in the near term.
